newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australian Broadcasting Corp Morning Update.
newsitem.headline: Australian Broadcasting Corp Morning Update.

text.p: 6 PERCENT WAGE RISE WANTED BY CONSTRUCTION UNION
The Construction Union says it will seek wage rises of at least six per cent for its members across Australia in enterprise agreements.
A meeting of the union's officials in Hobart has set six per cent as the least state offices should be able to achieve in enterprise bargaining.
But Secretary, John Sutton, says members in New South Wales, Victoria and Western Australia should expect bigger increases which local economies can withstand.
He says the union's approach is economically realistic, and agreement to a six per cent rise has already been reached with employers in Queensland and South Australia.
MAN FOUND IN HEAVY SEAS BY USE OF NIGHT VISION
A man missing for more than 10 hours in rough seas off Caloundra overnight has been found after a massive search.
The 26-year-old man from Deception Bay was found off the east coast of Bribie Island clinging to his overturned dingy by a rescue helicopter.
Seven rescue vessels started searching for the man after his fishing companion was found on a navigation beacon by a passing ship late yesterday.
Sergeant Richard Bartley from the Water Police says the man was freezing cold when found and is now on his way to Redcliffe Hospital.
He says the use of night vision technology proved crucial in the rescue.
NATIONAL DAY OF ACTION AT UNIVERSITIES
The National Union of Students has planned rallies and marches in most major centres around Australia today in a National Day of Action against funding cuts to higher education.
Union president John Carey says the battle against the introduction of up front fees and last year's budget cuts are the main issues.
Mr Carey says students want the budget cuts reversed, and will maintain pressure on the Coalition through to the next election.
The Day of action has the support of academics, and National Tertiary Education Union president, Carolyn Allport says in most centres, it will be a joint student-staff action.
Doctor Allport says the Union fully supports the fight against upfront fees, saying student anger is entirely justified.
BEAZLEY CONCERNED ABOUT AIRPORT COSTS AND CHARGES
The Federal Opposition says it doubts whether costs and charges will be monitored when the new owners of the Brisbane, Melbourne and Perth airports take control.
This follows yesterday's announcement that the three airports had been sold for a total of three-point-four billion dollars.
Labor leader Kim Beazley says he's concerned costs and charges to users of the airports are set to rise as the new owners seek returns on their investments.
Mr Beazley says he doubts whether the Government will police the issue.
NEW DEMOCRACY CLASSES FOR SCHOOL STUDENTS
The Federal Government is to spend more than 17-million dollars to encourage schools to educate young people between years four and 10 about Australia's democracy.
Schools Minister David Kemp says studies have shown a high level of ignorance among the population about the Constitution and the role of the Governor-General.
Dr Kemp says with Australia about to engage in a national debate about the constitution, it's important young people understand how the system works and the implications of any changes.
BHP DESCRIBED AS THE "BIGOTED AUSTRALIAN": MP
Mining giant BHP has come under further attack following its decision to close-down steelmaking in Newcastle, this time for alleged discrimination.
During debate in the New South Wales parliament last night, Government backbencher, Tony Stewart described BHP as the "bigoted Australian"
He quoted from what he said was a confidential BHP memo written in 1992, claiming its wording promoted discriminatory, pro-Anglo Saxon employment policies.
STOWAWAYS AND SAILOR FOUND IN RUGGED BUSHLAND
Twin teenage girls and their Malaysian companion, who jumped ship off North Queensland more than two weeks ago are in Cairns this morning for questioning by police and immigration officials.
Joanne and Sarah Ingham were invited onboard a cargo ship in New Zealand four months ago but fell asleep and awoke to find themselves at sea.
They hid from the Captain, while sailing to Australia via Singapore.
While off north Queensland the two girls and a Malaysian seaman jumped overboard, hid from search planes and drifted for 40 hours to Cape York Peninsula.
They were found in rugged country by a group of Aboriginal people near Coen.
LOSS, GRIEF AND TRAUMA CONFERENCE IN SYDNEY
More than 500 health and welfare professionals will attend a conference in Sydney over the next three days dealing with the issues of loss, grief and trauma.
The conference will be opened by former New South Wales Coroner Kevin Waller.
There'll be a special session on the Port Arthur massacre presented by the Tasmanian police psychologist.
DEATH PENALTY CLAIMS EXAGGERATED: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
The department of Foreign Affairs says reports that a 25-year-old Australian who's facing drug charges in the Middle East could face a death sentence have been exaggerated.
Flight attendant, Julia Alexander, from Melbourne has been in custody in Sharjah in the United Arab Emirates for three months on charges involving valium and marijuana.
Department spokesman, Tony Melville, says the Australian Consul General in Dubai has provided information to local officials about Australia's attitude towards soft drugs.
He says Ms Alexander's facing a maximum sentence of about four or five years in jail, which by Australian standards, is very high.
